TopicTitle: I got a new computer, is it SpaceEngine worthy?

Articles.Content:
Specs:

intel Core I3-4130 processor

8Gb of RAM

1 terrabyte of hard drive storage space

Unknown graphics card (presumably something from intel/GeForce)

OS: Windows 8.1

8 Gb of ram?! Nice!

I'm no expert on hardware, but this sounds really good to me. If you want the official specs for Space Engine you can find them here (just scroll down a bit): [http://en.spaceengine.org/](http://en.spaceengine.org/)

That should more than manage Space Engine. I think the only deciding factor will be the GPU, but if it's up to par with the rest of the system then it should be fine. Only thing is that there was a bit of a problem with certain versions of the nvidia drivers, I had to downggrade my drivers to get planets to display properly, but that was a version or two ago so it may have been fixed since then. Best way to tell is just to try it, of course ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

> 
> That should more than manage Space Engine. I think the only deciding factor will be the GPU, but if it's up to par with the rest of the system then it should be fine. Only thing is that there was a bit of a problem with certain versions of the nvidia drivers, I had to downggrade my drivers to get planets to display properly, but that was a version or two ago so it may have been fixed since then. Best way to tell is just to try it, of course ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)

The video card is actually quite relevant in Space Engine, as a lot of generation is done on the GPU.

Looks shiny !

Though knowing the precise model of the GPU is important, since it's internal memory is used for textures generated by SE. Knowing it's clock speed is also important.

I don't know much about SE but if you get a 2gb GPU (>750ti not sure what AMD equivalent is) youd practically be doubling the recommended specs. Even with a 1gb GPU youd still be able I handle it easily

> 
> The video card is actually quite relevant in Space Engine, as a lot of generation is done on the GPU.

That's what I was saying, how well it'll run will be dependant on the GPU, but given that the rest of the system has pretty good specs it's reasonable to assume it has a half decent video card as well.
Just found out the processor *is* the graphics card, and also that i'm using windows 8.1 **64-bit**. I've come across a pantheon of game-crippling bugs, hoping to eliminate all of them somehow.

So you mean that you have integrated graphics.

Here's something you can do to find out what brand of integrated graphics you have: 

1)Click on start

2)Type "Dxdiag" in the search bar, hit enter.

3) When the DxDiag window appears, click on the Display tab.

4) Post the listed name, chip type, memory ect here.

[Found a **big** wealth of info from Dxdiag.](http://pastebin.com/5xCuyQh8)

along with that, one of the major issues i'm having [has already been asked about on the spaceengine forums by my account that i made on it](http://en.spaceengine.org/forum/4-2896-1), but no other space engine forum members will bother to help me on it. Maybe you can analyze what's going on here?

**Edited <time datetime="2015-03-06T20:30:30Z" title="03/06/2015 08:30  PM" data-short="9 yr">March 6, 2015</time> by Souper**

First, update your graphics drivers as they are outdated/OEM drivers from the looks of it. [https://downloadcenter.intel.com/download/24596/Intel-Iris-and-HD-Graphics-Driver-for-Windows-7-8-8-1-64-bit](https://downloadcenter.intel.com/download/24596/Intel-Iris-and-HD-Graphics-Driver-for-Windows-7-8-8-1-64-bit)
It said my operating system was not supported when i tried to upgrade my driver.

> 
> Just found out the processor *is* the graphics card, and also that i'm using windows 8.1 **64-bit**. I've come across a pantheon of game-crippling bugs, hoping to eliminate all of them somehow.

Is it a laptop, by any chance? Because that would mean you can pretty much forget proper Space Engine performance.
Nope, it's a desktop.

If it's a desktop and you have some spare money you could buy a 2gb AMD card for pretty cheap and that'll smash your game performance up.

A good way to see if your PC will run certain games/applications is to go on [http://www.systemrequirementslab.com/cyri](http://www.systemrequirementslab.com/cyri) (not sure if SE is on it)

EDIT- After a quick search on the HP website of the product number that came up in the report I'm assuming [this](http://h20564.www2.hp.com/hpsc/doc/public/display?docId=emr_na-c04119419&DocLang=en&docLocale=en_US) is your computer

**Edited <time datetime="2015-03-08T22:38:24Z" title="03/08/2015 10:38  PM" data-short="9 yr">March 8, 2015</time> by LumberJack400**

Yup, that's mine.

also, i'm still battlign those graphical glitches, stay tuned to see if i win the fight! 9I'm currently in the phase of tinkering with the main.cfg and user.cfg)

**Edited <time datetime="2015-03-08T22:47:26Z" title="03/08/2015 10:47  PM" data-short="9 yr">March 8, 2015</time> by Souper**

> 
> a 2gb AMD card

Please be aware that the fact a card has 2 GB of RAM says as much about its performance as the day of the month. It is like saying your car is fast because it is red. Manufacturers know people often confuse the amount of RAM with actual performance, which is why you see so many underpowered cards with huge amounts of RAM, often of the slow GDDR3 type too. Pure marketing. Do note that the amount of RAM *can* influence performance negatively when there is too little or it is of the wrong type, but it will never *increase* performance when the GPU chip is weak.

The only way of knowing a card's performance are benchmarks done by an independent source.

> 
> Please be aware that the fact a card has 2 GB of RAM...

I understand that more RAM doesn't mean it's better, and that you should always check benchmarks, price for performance, compare the card to other cards of that price point /performance 

Sorry for the confusion

> 
> I understand that more RAM doesn't mean it's better, and that you should always check benchmarks, price for performance, compare the card to other cards of that price point /performance 
> Sorry for the confusion

No worries, the statement was intended as one in general. I just used your post to inform those that do not know, as some people get confused by it ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)
I've never played Space Engine. What is it?
It's only the single greatest proceduraly generated universe game of all time is what it is!

> 
> It's only the single greatest proceduraly generated universe game of all time is what it is!

What do you do in it?

> 
> What do you do in it?

Nothing and everything. It is not a game, it is the universe. You can fly around the known and unknown universe, visit planets, stars, moons, galaxies, you name it. Discover life, watch a binary star set, see what the universe looks like from Andromeda.

We are sadly born before the great age of space exploration, but this is pretty amazingly close. It widened my perception of the universe like no other single information source.
Good news! After using [this](http://en.spaceengine.org/forum/4-2716-1), i have completely wiped out all the glitches i mentioned earlier and now am ready to begin an exploration post!
I have all specs except GPU, Will an Intel HD 3000 work?
